contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox settlement |name = Urlingford |other_name = {{pad top italic|Áth na nUrlainn}} |settlement_type = Town |image_skyline = The Mason's Apron.jpg |image_caption = The Mason's Apron, Urlingford |pushpin_map = Ireland |pushpin_label_position = right |pushpin_map_caption = Location in Ireland |coordinates_display = inline,title |coordinates_region = IE |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] |subdivision_type1 = [[Provinces of Ireland|Province]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Leinster]] |subdivision_type3 = [[Counties of Ireland|County]] |subdivision_name3 = [[County Kilkenny]] |established_title = |established_date = |unit_pref = Metric |area_footnotes = |area_total_km2 = |population_as_of = 2006 |population_footnotes = |population_total = |population_urban = 867 |population_density_km2 = auto |timezone1 = [[West European Time|WET]] |utc_offset1 = +0 |timezone1_DST = [[Irish Standard Time|IST]] ([[Western European Summer Time|WEST]]) |utc_offset1_DST = -1 |latd = 52.7203 |longd = -7.5826 |coordinates_format = dms |coordinates_type = dim:100000_region:IE |elevation_footnotes = |elevation_m = |blank_name = Irish Grid Reference |blank_info = <!-- {{iem4ibx|??????}} --> |website = |footnotes = }} '''Urlingford''' ({{Irish place name|Áth na nUrlainn}}) is a [[town]] in the [[Barony (Ireland)|barony]] of [[Barony of Galmoy|Galmoy]], [[County Kilkenny]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. The town lies on the [[R639 road|R639]]. The [[M8 motorway (Ireland)|M8 motorway]] runs just west of the town, from which both Urlingford and nearby [[Johnstown, County Kilkenny|Johnstown]] are accessed via junction four. Urlingford is a bus hub, with major operator [[JJ Kavanagh and Sons]] based there.<ref>[http://www.jjkavanagh.ie/ JJ Kavanagh Bus Company]</ref> Situated {{convert|125|km|mi|abbr=on}} from [[Dublin]] and {{convert|129|km|mi|abbr=on}} from [[Cork (city)|Cork]], Urlingford has long been a resting-point for travellers half way between the Republic of Ireland's two largest cities, as a result, both the [[Bus Eireann]] Dublin to Cork bus service calls here. the town had a huge success when the Emeralds GAA club won the minor A in 2000 and then the junior in 2001. Alan Guilfoyle was crucial in both wins. The Irish name ''Áth na nUrlainn'' means "ford of the slaughter" and has been anglicised as ''Aghnenurlin'', ''Aghnenoorlin'', ''Awnanoorlin'' and similar.<ref>[http://www.logainm.ie/27524.aspx Placenames Database of Ireland] (see archival records)</ref> ==See also== * [[List of towns and villages in the Republic of Ireland|List of towns and villages in Ireland]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{County Kilkenny}} [[Category:Towns and villages in County Kilkenny]] [[Category:Census towns in County Kilkenny]] {{Kilkenny-geo-stub}}
